title-group.article-title: Investigation of Short-term Variations in Term Breast Milk Composition during Repeated Breast Expression Sessions

article-meta.aff: 1School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, The University of Western Australia, Crawley, Western Australia, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Anna R. Hepworth, School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, The University of Western Australia, M310, 35 Stirling Hwy, Crawley, Western Australia, Australia Email: anna.hepworth@uwa.edu.au

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Breast milk composition can be affected by several factors, and it can exhibit short-term (weekly) variations. Investigating variations in breast milk composition is important to accurately estimate nutrient requirements of the infant.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To investigate short-term changes in breast milk composition between left and right breasts, over a 3-week period within the first 6 months of lactation.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: The left and right breasts of the mothers of healthy, term infants (n = 23) were simultaneously expressed with an electric breast pump for 15 minutes, on 3 occasions within 3 weeks. Milk samples (5 mL) were collected from the total expression volume of each breast at each session. The macronutrient contents, total solids, and energy content were determined using a mid-infrared human milk analyzer. Mothers (n = 17) measured their 24-hour milk production, and the average 24-hour fat contents were also determined.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Over the 3 weekly sessions, no significant changes were found in macronutrient contents. On average, total solids (P = .04) and energy (P = .04) decreased by week 3 of follow-up sessions from 14 to 13 g/100 mL and from 82 to 76 Kcal/100 mL, respectively; however, these changes became insignificant when expression volume was taken into account. The macronutrient concentration was similar for the left and right breasts; however, milk composition varied markedly between mothers. Furthermore, average 24-hour fat content was significantly lower than the mean fat content from a single expression session (P < .01).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Our findings highlight that when determining the nutritional adequacy of a mother’s milk, assuming an average concentration requires caution. The study findings illustrate the importance of using average 24-hour fat content of milk to obtain representative measures of infant energy intake.

sec.title: Well Established
sec.p: Several factors are known to affect breast milk composition; however, little information is available regarding the week-to-week variations in breast milk macronutrient content during established lactation.

sec.title: Newly Expressed
sec.p: This study was designed to characterize the short-term (weekly) variations in breast milk macronutrient composition within and between mothers. The result showed no change in macronutrient concentration over the 3 weekly sessions within mothers, but there were marked variations in milk composition between mothers.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Wide variations have been reported in the concentration of energy-yielding macronutrients (ie, fat, protein, and lactose) in breast milk both within and between individual mothers.1,2 Breast milk composition is affected by several factors including length of pregnancy, mother’s diet, stage of lactation, changes during a feed, and time of day.1,3-5 Protein concentration has been shown to decrease in the early stages of lactation, whereas fat content decreases and then increases as lactation progresses.1 In addition, a 2- to 3-fold change has been observed in the fat content of human milk over the course of a breastfeed,4,6 which accounts for the high variability observed in the energy content of human milk.7 Therefore, all levels of variation should be taken into account to accurately determine the nutrient content of milk.

Most previous studies investigating macronutrient variation in term human milk are based on milk samples obtained during early lactation.1,8,9 Only a few investigators have analyzed milk samples from late lactation, and to our knowledge, no study has investigated the week-to-week macronutrient variation in established lactation despite the reports of acute changes in milk composition during this period.10,11 In addition, considerable variation in breast milk volume was found between individual mothers and at different stages of lactation12,13; however, little information is available regarding the influence of variations in breast milk volume on breast milk composition.

Since breast milk composition is not uniform, the variability in breast milk composition could potentially influence the volume of milk consumed by the breastfed infant, either at each breastfeed or during the day.14,15 Therefore, increasing our understanding of the factors responsible for the variation in breast milk composition may help explain the different feeding patterns in breastfed infants. Furthermore, without sufficient information regarding the variation in milk composition, it is difficult to recommend the appropriate method of milk sample collection for measurement of milk constituents to estimate infants’ nutrient requirements and energy intake.

This study aimed to develop a better understanding of the time-dependent variations in human milk composition during established lactation. We analyzed the macronutrients, total solids, and energy in term milk samples over a 3-week period within the first 6 months of lactation, and if the mother continued breastfeeding, at 6, 9, and 12 months of lactation.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: Twenty-three mothers of healthy term infants participated in this study. Mothers were recruited through the West Australian branch of the Australian Breastfeeding Association and the Child and Adolescent Community Health Nurses in the Oceanic Region.

Breast milk samples were collected on 3 occasions over a 3-week period within the first 6 months of lactation. Some mothers also provided 1 or more additional samples at 6 (n = 7), 9 (n = 7), or 12 (n = 4) months. Participating mothers were also asked to measure their 24-hour milk production. All mothers provided written informed consent to participate in the study, which was approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee of The University of Western Australia.

sec.title: Sampling
sec.p: Mothers performed a 15-minute simultaneous expression of left and right breasts using two separate electric breast pumps (Symphony, Medela AG, Switzerland) on 3 occasions within 3 weeks and repeating a single session at 6, 9 and 12 months, at the Breastfeeding Centre at King Edward Memorial Hospital, Subiaco, Western Australia.16 Milk samples were collected at each session from each breast at the beginning (pre, 1-2 mL), middle (mid, 5 mL), and end (post, 1-2 mL) of the expression session. The total volume of milk expressed during each session was recorded.
Samples were transported on ice to the laboratory, where they were stored at -20°C until further analysis.

sec.title: Mid-Infrared Analysis
sec.p: As described previously,17 a mid-infrared human milk analyzer (HMA; Miris AB, Uppsala, Sweden) was used to determine the macronutrient (protein, fat, and lactose), total solids, and energy content of the breast milk.

Mid milk samples (5 mL), collected from the total expression volume of each breast from each expression session, were used to analyze the macronutrient and energy content. Prior to analysis, all samples were thawed, warmed to 40°C in a digital water bath, and homogenized (1.5 seconds per 1 mL of sample) using an ultrasonic processor VCX130 (Sonics & Material, Newton, Connecticut, USA). Then a 2-mL sample was injected into the HMA for analysis using the HMA calibration mode of processed (homogenized) milk. All samples were analyzed in duplicate.
The interassay coefficient of variation (CV) for fat, protein, lactose, and total solids was 4.4% (SD 0.1%), 4.4% (SD 0.1%), 3.0% (SD 0.2%), and 3.1% (SD 0.3%), respectively (n = 50).

sec.title: Twenty-Four-Hour Milk Production Measurements
sec.p: Mothers measured their 24-hour milk production by weighing their baby before and after each feed, for each breast, using an electronic scale (Baby Weigh Scale, Medela AG). Mothers recorded the volume taken by the infant at each feed from each breast. Test weighing was done at each mother’s home for a period of 24-28 hours, and the measurements were later corrected to 24 hours, with no correction made for infant insensible water loss.18 In addition, mothers collected and froze the small (1-2 mL) milk samples into 5-mL propylene vials (Disposable Products Pty Ltd, Adelaide, Australia) before (pre) and immediately after (post) each weighing.

sec.title: Creamatocrit Analysis
sec.p: The cream and fat content of all the milk samples collected during expression sessions and those collected during the 24-hour milk production study was also measured by the creamatocrit method,19 using the Creamatocrit Plus device (Medela, Inc, McHenry, Illinois, USA). Cream content of the milk is related to degree of breast fullness20; therefore, the measurement of cream content in the samples was used to calculate the initial degree of fullness of each breast, for each expression session,21 and the amount of milk available in the breast before expression.22

The mean 24-hour fat content was determined as described by Mitoulas et al.1 Briefly, pre- and post-feed milk fat contents were averaged to provide the fat content for each feed. The amount of fat consumed by the infant at each feed was then determined from the volume of the feed. The sum of the amount of fat for all feeds and the total volume consumed over the study period was then used to determine an average 24-hour fat content.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using the R program, version 2.7.2.23 The package nlme was used for linear mixed-effect modeling 2.24

Milk intake variables (24-hour milk production of each breast) were compared using the paired Student’s t test. The differences between macronutrient concentrations across the 3-week period were tested using linear mixed-effect models with the inclusion of week as a factor and with 2 possible random effects, the effect of mother, and breast within mother. Models were run for the explanatory variable (weekly interval) and for each response variable (fat, protein, lactose, total solids, energy, and volume expressed). The difference between the mean fat content at a single expression session and the mean 24-hour fat content was also tested using linear mixed-effect models.

To test for similarities and differences in milk composition between the left and right breasts, the absolute difference between breasts at each sampling point was calculated for each of the composition variables, and then linear mixed-effect models were used to test whether the differences were significantly different from zero. There were some missing values in the data (the complete 6-sample set was not obtained from 7 of the mothers); these missing data were taken into account in the analysis.

Owing to the scarcity of follow-up data at 6, 9, and 12 months, analysis was restricted to separately comparing each follow-up time point with the initial data for that subset of mothers, using a linear mixed-effects model with composition as the response, and time factor as the predictor. In addition, lattice plots were created to determine any longitudinal differences in these mothers’ milk composition.

Univariate relationships between expression variables (volume expressed, degree of breast fullness, available milk in the breast, and percentage of available milk removed) and milk composition were tested with linear mixed-effects modeling.
All values are reported as mean ± standard deviation, unless otherwise stated. P < .05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: All infants (n = 23) were fully breastfed on demand. The median age was 2.4 months (range, 0.9-5.6 mo), and most were male (n = 17). The mean age of the participating mothers was 33 ± 3.0 years (range, 28-39 y), and most were primiparous (n = 16, 70%). Of the 23 mothers participating in this study, 17 measured their 24-hour milk production. The mean 24-hour milk intake of the infants was 722 ± 136 g (range, 467-921 g), and there was no significant difference between the 24-hour milk production between the left (370 ± 109 g; range, 138-522 g) and right (352 ± 121g; range, 85-583 g) breasts.

sec.title: Milk Composition over Time and between Breasts
sec.p: The results of the biochemical analysis of macronutrient composition in milk samples over the 3-week period are listed in Table 1. Box plots showing the distribution of data are depicted in Figure 1. Over the 3-week period, no significant change was observed in fat, protein, or lactose concentration (P = .06, P = .51 and P = .86, respectively). However, significant time-dependent variations were observed in total solids (P = .04) and energy (P = .04), with an average decrease of 0.27 g and 2.4 kcal per 100 mL each week during the 3-week period, respectively. Both were significantly lower at week 3 (P = .04) when compared with weeks 1 and 2 (Table 1). The changes in total solids and energy became insignificant when expression volume was taken into account.

caption.p: Breast Milk Macronutrient Concentration across Weekly Intervals, Mean ± SD (N = 23)

fn.p: Combined values of left and right breasts for samples collected over a 3-week period. Same-letter superscripts are significantly different from each other (P < .05).

caption.p: Distribution of Fat, Protein, Lactose, Total Solids, and Energy Content of Breast Milk across 3 Weeks (N = 23)
Weekly intervals (weeks 1, 2, and 3) are indicated. Box plots illustrate the median (indicated by the bold line), quartiles (box), range (error bars), and outliers (o).

sec.p: Protein concentration was significantly decreased (P < .01), whereas fat was significantly increased (P = .02) at the 6-month follow-up, but no change was detected after that (Table 2). Furthermore, lactose concentration was found to be similar during follow-up measurements (Table 2).

caption.p: Breast Milk Macronutrient Concentration at Follow-up Periods, Mean ± SD (N = 11)

fn.p: Data for the samples collected on 3 occasions within 3 weeks are combined for the mothers who participated in the study up to 12 mo. There were 7, 7, and 4 mothers who repeated the single breast expression session and provided the samples at 6, 9, and 12 mo of lactation, respectively.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Indicates a significant difference (P < .05) between the follow-up values and the the 3-week values for that subset of mothers.

sec.p: There was no significant difference between the milk from the left and right breasts of a mother in fat content (left 5.5 ± 1.8 g/100 mL; right 5.7 ± 1.8 g/100 mL; P = .44), total solids (left 13 ± 1.8 g/100 mL; right 13 ± 1.7 g/100 mL; P = .48), energy (left 79 ± 16 kcal/100 mL; right 81 ± 16 kcal/100 mL; P = .45), concentration of protein (left 1.0 ± 0.2 g/100 mL; right 1.0 ± 0.2 g/100 mL; P = .97) or lactose (left 6.3 ± 0.3 g/100 mL; right 6.2 ± 0.3 g/100 mL; P = .45) across the weekly intervals (Figure 2). However, in 5 mothers, consistent differences in protein concentration between breasts were observed. These mothers were found to have a consistently higher protein concentration in 1 breast compared to the other for all samples collected over 3 weeks (Figure 2). The mean absolute difference in the protein concentration of milk from the left and right breast for the whole group of mothers (n = 23) was 0.2 ± 0.1 g/100 mL (range, 0-1 g/100 mL).

caption.p: Difference in Fat, Protein, and Lactose Concentration between Breasts in Individual Mothers

Differences are calculated by subtracting left breast fat, protein, and lactose values from the right breast. A negative value on the graph indicates that the right breast has higher concentration, and a positive value indicates that the left breast has higher concentration. Each mother is represented by different symbols, and the same set of symbols represents the weekly visits of each mother. The graph shows some consistent differences in left and right breast protein concentration in mothers 3(■), 8 (⊕), 12 (*), 16(□), and 22(<) in each of the 3 weekly sessions.

sec.p: Marked variations were observed in macronutrient and energy content between individual mothers across weekly intervals. Protein content of milk samples showed a 3-fold difference ranging from 0.5-1.4 g/100 mL (median, 1.0 g/100 mL; interquartile range [IQR] 0.9-1.1 g/100 mL). Lactose ranged from 4.7-7.0 g/100 mL (median, 6.4 g/100 mL; IQR 6.1-6.4 g/100 mL). The fat content ranged from 1.3-10.5 g/100 mL (median, 5.6 g/100 mL; IQR 4.5-6.7 g/100 mL). In addition, total solids and energy showed the same pattern of variation as the fat content (Figure 3); total solids ranged from 9-18 g/100 mL (median, 13 g/100 mL; IQR 12-14 g/100 mL) and energy content from 43-123 kcal/100 mL (median 79 kcal/100 mL; IQR 69-89 kcal/100 mL).

caption.p: Pattern of Variation in Fat, Total Solids, and Energy in Each of the 23 Mothers
Values are from week 2, left breast samples and are sorted by the milk fat content.

sec.p: The fat, protein, and lactose content of milk samples were not associated with either gestational age or sex of the infant.

sec.title: Milk Composition and Expression Characteristics
sec.p: There was no significant difference in the expression volume between the left and right breasts (P = .15). Over the weekly sessions, the total expression volume was significantly increased by week 3 of the follow-up sessions (P = .03), from 64 to 79 mL.

Significant negative associations were found between the fat, total solids, and energy content and the expression volume (P < .01), initial degree of breast fullness (P < .01), and amount of available milk in the breast (P < .01); higher fat and energy contents were associated with lower expression volumes, lower amounts of available milk, and lower degrees of breast fullness. In contrast, no significant relationship was seen between protein and lactose concentration with expression volume (P = .35 and P = .40), degree of breast fullness (P = .76 and P = .08), or amount of available milk in the breast (P = .15 and P = .07). However, for 5 mothers with consistent between-breast differences, a significant relationship was observed between protein concentration and the volume of milk expressed from each breast (P = .01), in that lower expression volume was associated with higher protein concentration. In addition, there was no significant relationship between the percentages of available milk removed and the macronutrient and energy content of milk.

sec.title: Comparison of Fat Content from A Single Expression Session to the 24-Hour Fat Value
sec.p: The mean fat content from a single expression session, which represents the 1 off sample of 24-hours, was compared to the 24-hour fat content. The mean 24-hour fat content (4.3 ± 0.8 g/100 mL; range, 2.4-6.1 g/100 mL) was found to be significantly lower than the mean fat content from a single expression session (ie, 1 off sample of 24-hours; P < .01), with a mean absolute difference of 1.4 ± 0.79 g/100 mL (range, 0.1-3.3 g/100 mL). The difference between fat content from a single expression session and 24-hour fat content was not statistically significant for left (1.4 ± 0.9 g/100 mL, range, 0.1-2.9 g/100 mL) and right breast (1.5 ± 0.7 g/100 mL; range, 0.5-3.3 g/100 mL; Figure 4). The difference in the measured fat content of milk samples collected from the 2 different sampling protocols was inversely associated with the total expression volume (P < .01), not with 24-hour milk production.

caption.p: Absolute Differences between Mean Fat Content from a Single Expression Session (1 off Sample of 24-Hours) and 24-Hour Fat Content for Left and Right Breast in Individual Mothers (n = 16)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To understand the time-dependent variations in milk composition, this study reports on changes in breast milk composition during established lactation on 3 occasions within 3 weeks in mothers of term infants. The milk production and intake characteristics of participating mother–infant pairs were variable, but the milk production of all participants was within the normal range.5

Changes have been reported in breast milk composition in relation to growth and development of the infant.1,25,26 Protein concentration has previously been reported to decrease with the progress of lactation, rapidly during the first month and then slowly until 6 months, and it then remains relatively constant.3,27,28 Similarly, a rapid increase in lactose concentration was reported in the first few days of lactation, after which the lactose concentration remained constant throughout the first year of lactation3,27; however, fat content decreases and then increases over the course of lactation.1 Our study showed that there were no changes in protein or lactose concentrations in the short term (across a 3-week period), which is similar to previous reports of no circadian1 and within-feed6 variations in these macronutrients. Although fat content is more variable29 and can vary within a feed and diurnally,4,30 no significant changes (only a decreasing trend at the third week) were observed in fat content in the short term (across a 3-week period), whereas short-term changes in total solids and energy content were related to the expressed milk volume. Furthermore, changes observed in samples collected during the follow-up visits at 6, 9, and 12 months were similar to those previously reported.1,3

These results showed that unlike early and late stages of lactation, which are characterized by considerable alterations in the composition, during established lactation, breast milk composition is not sensitive to short-term variations (Figure 1).

Although we did not find significant differences in any of the measured macronutrients (fat, protein, and lactose) between milk from the left and right breasts, some mothers (n = 5) did have consistent between-breast differences in protein concentration (Figure 2). This variation was linked to the volume of milk expressed from each breast; each mother had 1 breast that expressed at least 25% more milk than the other at all 3 weekly intervals, and this higher expression volume was associated with lower milk protein content. This negative association between protein concentration and expression volume may be caused by a dilutional effect resulting from increased milk production.31 The individual differences and the similarity in milk composition between the left and right breasts suggest that milk synthesis and secretion are controlled by both local (autocrine) and systemic factors.4,32,33

The relationship that exists between the fat content of milk and the degree of breast fullness has previously been established.20 It has been shown that the increase in fat content over the course of a feed is related to the degree of breast emptying; in other words, the fat content increases steeply as the breast is emptied.5,20 In showing a negative association between fat content and degree of fullness, the present study is in agreement with these prior studies.28,34 However, for 8% (n = 10 samples) of the pairs of pre- and post-milk samples in this study, the higher fat content was observed in pre-milk as compared to post-milk. This difference in the changes in fat content between pre- and post-milk might be a result of the differences in either degree of fullness among mammary lobes or inconsistent emptying of various sectors of the breast.5,34

Variation observed in the total solids and energy content of milk needs to be considered with the fact that fat is the major contributor to these components and provides up to 50% of infant energy requirements.29 Therefore, these variables are not independent of each other and showed the same pattern of variation as in fat (Figure 3). This finding needs to be considered when interpreting these variables, that is, the same variability and influencing factors will be found for total solids and energy content as the fat. However, our results indicate that protein and lactose levels are not affected by degree of breast fullness and other expression characteristics, and therefore, these factors do not need to be considered when measuring these components.

The mean 24-hour fat content and protein and lactose concentrations in the present study are similar to those reported by other investigators.1,29,35 The large difference in mean fat content between the single expression session and over the 24-hour period (Figure 4) indicates variation in the pattern of emptying of the breast. Infants empty the breast to a varying extent throughout the day, presumably according to their appetite. Therefore, to accurately estimate the mean fat content of a mother’s milk and infant energy intake, it is important to determine the fat content from each feed from each breast over the day.

This study highlighted the variability in breast milk composition between mothers, and consequently, the average macronutrient content that they supply to their infants. Of the 3 major macronutrients (fat, protein, and lactose), the highest variation was observed in fat content compared to protein and lactose (CV of 34%, 19%, and 5%, respectively). Limitations of the study are the small number of mothers participating in follow-up sessions at different stages of lactation, as well as the limited descriptive (such as absence of body mass index) data from these mothers. The anthropometric data of the mothers could be helpful in explaining the inter-individual differences in the milk macronutrient concentration observed in this study.

The differences in milk composition between mothers support the idea that each mother’s milk is unique and likely suited to the needs of her own infant. Therefore, assuming an average concentration to determine the nutrient and energy intake of individual breastfed infants requires caution, especially when recommending earlier, complementary feeding for infants based on their growth rate without knowing the actual composition of their mother’s milk. Furthermore, the variation observed in breast milk composition between mothers may relate to the individual feeding patterns observed in mother–infant dyads, but this hypothesis requires further investigation.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, no short-term (week-to-week) variations were observed in breast milk composition during established lactation. Therefore, when sampling for nutritional studies, it is not necessary to account for these weekly variations. However, we found that the mean 24-hour fat content was consistently lower than the mean fat content from a single expression session by approximately 13 g/L. This finding highlights that to estimate the average fat content of the milk consumed by the infant during the day, determining the fat content of milk samples collected over 24 hours is a valuable method to obtain representative measures of infant energy intake.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: The study was supported by the Higher Education Commission (Pakistan) and an unrestricted research grant from Medela AG (Switzerland).
